I was hurrying through the lower level of a modern shopping mall, but it looked like it had been completely cleared out - as if if was being used for a movie set. I knew, but did not see, that it was now attached to a subway system, and that the reason I was walking there was that LaFashionista and her boyfriend were ahead of me, trying to catch a train, and I needed to catch up with them.

 

Instead of being filled with people, kiosks, planters, and colourful advertisements, the atrium space was grey bare and sterile. The pillars were of f white in colour, the floor a speckled grey linoleum, and the light was not artificial , but natural , flooding in from the upper stories. There were no shops in the niches around the atrium, only empty archways.

As i neared the place which I presumed to be the entrance to the underground/ subway system, I saw that this part of the mall had debris on the floor –mostly broken glass, but also broken bottles of different colours. Still, the place was silent, empty of people, and there was no dirt or other debris – just the broken glass. I could not see and areas of damaged or broken glass, so could only conclude they came from above.

I was not alarmed, but somehow I knew that I should not continue to pursue Karen and Tyler, but continued to the opposite corner of the atrium. There was an area that had aluminium cafe tables and chairs, and looked out through glass window-walls to a sunken garden.

I was out at a dance the other week with (of course) a small group of lovely women, some of whom were out dancing without their wives' company. That did spark a conversation about social expectations in the tight-knit lesbian community. It was one of the women's dances where the "single ladies" are encouraged to buy a glow-stick bracelet to indicate their status - and none of us were buying. I brought my new roomie along even though she is mostly interested in men, because she loves dancing and was hoping for some good music.

The tall femme is married to a older butch who also enjoys dancing, but is far less social. I have seen dance together in the past, doing that ballroom thing that seems to appeal to my demographic, and they fit together well. But at other times Tall Femme goes dancing on her own, and is aware of the looks in her direction from others in the community who expect her and her partner to be joined at the hip. They've worked out their own social routine, so no one else should really care - but Tall Femme is aware that she has to be discreet in public, sitting out the slow dances, and not getting too close. It's something she's gotten used to, this compartmentalization of her life. Many of her family are Mormon, and although she enjoys spending time with them (including her seventy-five nieces and nephews), not all of them accept or fully understand that she is gay.

She mentioned that they had been together for 12 years, and married when they could. "That's like forty in het years," she laughed. "Why is that?", New Roomie asked. Tall Femme explained that gay couples don't get the social support that mixed couples do, and relationships suffer because of that. There's an irony there, that a society that refuses to accept same-sex relationships can also criticize gays for having a short-term, unstable relationships. The flip side (especially I think for lesbians) is the U-Haul syndrome, in which unsuited couples meet, quickly move in together, and stay in the relationship even when it's not working, because it's so difficult being alone, and so difficult to find the right person.

It made me remember that actor from  Welcome Back Kotter, Ron Pallilo, who was sixty-three (too young, we would say), when he died of a heart attack this year. He was survived by his partner of forty-one years. Now that's an amazing amount of time for any couple to be together, but even more so for a gay couple. I remember thinking how wonderful it must have been for them, to find one's soulmate  so early in life. But if "gay years" are worth 3 and 1/3 "het years", then even a ten-year same-sex relationship is quite an achievement.

I had a great time, and more importantly I had enough energy to go to my favourite dance venue that evening.

The Rowing Club has a perfect view of Vancouver Harbour, and I have friends who can be depended to save me a ringside seat on the deck. It's a necessity, because even when the weather is so-so, the dance floor is gets hot real fast. Dancing at the rowing club is like going to a sauna - or perhaps an energetic version of hot yoga. You jump in for a few songs, then grab some liquid and cool off on the deck, as you watch the sky darken, the downtown towers light up, and the moon rise over the water. It's an over-forty scene, but by the end of the evening everyone is pogoing on the dance floor like we were all seventeen. And there are always a few hot 20-somethings who seem to have got the wrong address, but are aiming to misbehave.
I had a particularly good time. I brought a woman who had never, in all her years in Vancouver, attended one of this DJ's dances, so she was fresh meat in the eyes of horny lesbians looking to hook up over Pride weekend. I've said that it's no wonder that 90% of lesbian couples seem to have Pride weekend as their anniversary. I exaggerate of course, but I suspect that U-Haul has to bring in extra moving vans for the following week. It was fun to watch my date as various women tried to chat her up - and to watch her flirt right back. A couple of drunk hotties were flashing in exchange for beads, and women dancing in lines, circles, couples, and solo. The best thing of all was knowing that that very hot woman, while revelling in the attention, was going home with me.

On Tuesday evening, I travelled through a rare electrical storm to attend Queerotica, a long-standing event that started as a fund-raiser for the Little Sister's Bookstore obscenity case. I suppose someone might point at the thunder and lightning as proof of some angry god, but it made an excellent backdrop for the readings, as light flashed and rain beat against the converted railway roundhouse. Not all of it the readings or the readers were all that good, but there were a few highlights. The only poetry of the evening came from C.E. Gatchalian, who puts words together wonderfully and reads them well. Hiromi Goto was charming, as she posed the twin questions: "How can I say I am a writer when I am not writing?" and "Am I still a lesbian if I'm not having sex?" And Michael V. Smith had the mostly-lesbian audience in the palm of his hand with a coming-of-age story of anonymous outdoor gay sex. There was much laughter throughout the evening, which I think is essential in the world of erotica. There is always a bit of the ridiculous about the act of sex, even when it is done by the most attractive people in the most attractive ways. 

There is more to look forward to - the Queer Film festival is yet to come, and perhaps, for next year, some projects of my own.

My friend in hospital got a new set of lungs on Saturday. This seems quite miraculous. It wasn't until they had decided to go forward with the surgery that they told her wife exactly how dire it was: they could have kept her alive another month on oxygen - maybe two, but that was unlikely.

She's not out of the woods yet - in fact, she's not even awake yet. Last night we were talking about what it would be like to be sedated for that long; this is day five, and they don't expect to bring her out of it until Friday.
It's been quite a ride for those closest to her. I've just been cheering on the sidelines for this one, popping into the hospital briefly, making sure her wife got something to eat  that wasn't hospital cafeteria food, that sort of thing. And mostly listening, because there's a lot of emotion that gets pushed aside while you're playing the waiting game.

Escaping from the cool weather and gloomy skies of Vancouver, I hit the road with a pal of mine, and headed for downtown Seattle, in search of Creole food and lesbian bars. Not disappointed on either score: now I know what red beans and rice are really all about (fresh sage in this case), and had a wonderfully relaxing time in the no-hanky-panky bathhouse, followed by girl watching in the bar upstairs. Sadly, there was no pool table, but can't complain. The waiter gave us beads that colour-coordinated with our outfits for a little fun - although later, in the washroom, I noticed that the shade of blue actually matched my bra strap, not my tank top.

Sometime during the evening, I started to feel a like an Edmontonian wearing shorts in Vegas in January. Locals were drifting in wearing leather jackets, cardigan sweaters, and hoodies in those muted shades of grey that are so typical of the PNW. There I was sitting comfortably in my tank tops, my companion in a tshirt and shorts, while the Seattleites huddled against the cold. After temperatures in the teens, Seattle at 23 degrees felt like summer to me.
